Info Gallery

Info

Trains of Ruegen
RE9 RE27 Zu|g|ebringer Racing Roland

RE9
Stralsund - Sassnitz; Baltic resort Binz

Sassnitz
Sassnitz is the white harbor town by the sea, it has about 10,000 residents, with that, it is the second-largest city. She owns a port where until 2000 the \"Stenaline\" a ferry to Trelleborg (Sweden) was departing. From this port, freight trains were shipped to the USSR during the GDR era.
Lancken
Lancken is a part of Sassnitz. This station is only equipped for the essentials, such as an intercom system, a timetable, and a shelter. In addition, there is a track to the chalk mine.
Sagard
Sagard is a small town with 2,460 residents. Her train station looks more modern than Lancken's.
Baltic resort Binz
The Baltic resort Binz train station is the main train station of the popular seaside resort Binz on the island of Ruegen. It was opened on May 15, 1939. The reception building dates back to 1938 and is still in operation today. The station has three platform tracks and is accessible for people with disabilities. It is regularly served by regional and long-distance trains, offering connections to cities such as Berlin, Hamburg, and Munich. The central location of the station allows travelers to reach the town center, the pier, and the fine sandy beach within a few minutes on foot. In addition, there is a connection to public transportation and taxis at the station, making it easy to continue traveling within Binz and beyond.
Lietzow (Ruegen)
The Lietzow (Ruegen) train station was opened in 1891 as a stop on the Stralsund–Sassnitz railway line and is located on the southern edge of Lietzow. Since 1939, the railway line to Binz branches off here, making Lietzow an important transfer point on the island of Ruegen. In 2009/10, an extensive renovation of the station took place, during which the number of main tracks was reduced to four. Today, the station is served by regional trains of the Ostdeutsche Eisenbahn GmbH (ODEG), which offer connections between Rostock, Stralsund, Sassnitz, and Binz. However, there is always a shuttle train that goes to the other stop.
Bergen(Ruegen)
Bergen is the district town of Ruegen and is the most populous city on Ruegen. It is one of the central traffic hubs of the island of Ruegen. It has facilities such as bicycle parking, parking spaces, and taxis. The DB Travel Center offers personal consultation and ticket sales.
Teschenhagen
The Teschenhagen station is located in the municipality of Sehlen on the island of Ruegen and was opened on July 1, 1883. It is located on the Stralsund–Sassnitz railway line and has two tracks with corresponding platforms. Originally designed as a train station with freight traffic, Teschenhagen now serves as a stop for regional trains of the Ostdeutsche Eisenbahn GmbH (ODEG), which offer connections between Rostock, Stralsund, and Sassnitz or Binz. The historic reception building is still intact and was partially inhabited until mid-2022.
Samtens
The Samtens train station is located on the outskirts of the eponymous municipality on Ruegen. It is also located on the Stralsund–Sassnitz railway line and is served by regional trains of the ODEG. After the expansion of the Electronic Signal Box (ESTW) from Altefaehr to Bergen, the station is unstaffed. The platforms were modernized, with the main platform being renovated and a new outer platform towards Bergen being constructed.
Rambin (Ruegen)
The Rambin (Ruegen) station was opened on July 1, 1883, on the Stralsund–Sassnitz railway line and is located on the outskirts of the municipality of Rambin. It has two tracks with corresponding platforms and is also served by regional trains of the ODEG, which offer hourly connections between Rostock, Stralsund, and the seaside resorts of the island of Ruegen. The historic reception building is still present, but no longer in operation.
Altefaehr
The Altefaehr train station is located about one kilometer southeast of the center of Altefaehr on the island of Ruegen, just around 200 meters from the Strelasund. It was opened on July 1, 1883, and is located on the Stralsund–Sassnitz railway line. Before the construction of the Ruegen Causeway in the 1930s, Altefaehr was only accessible by ferry; the original station was then located closer to the ferry terminal. Today, regional express trains of the Ostdeutsche Eisenbahn GmbH (ODEG) stop here every two hours on the route from Rostock via Stralsund to Sassnitz or Binz. The central location of the station allows travelers to reach the town center and the waterfront promenade on foot in just a few minutes.
Stralsund Ruegendamm
The Stralsund station Ruegendamm, also known as Ruegendamm Station, was opened on October 5, 1936, and is located on the Stralsund–Sassnitz railway line. It is located a few meters before the Ziegelgraben Bridge, which connects Stralsund with the island of Ruegen. The station has a partially covered central platform and is served by regional trains of the ODEG, which offer connections between Rostock, Stralsund, and Sassnitz or Binz. Parking is available in front of the station, and there is a connection to public transportation. A ticket counter or other service facilities are not available, however.
Stralsund
Stralsund Hauptbahnhof, opened in 1863 and redesigned in 1905 in neo-Gothic style, is the main railway hub of the Hanseatic city. It connects northern Germany with the island of Ruegen and major cities like Berlin and Hamburg. The RE9 regional train runs every two hours between Rostock and Lietzow, continuing alternately to Sassnitz or Ostseebad Binz. The station offers six tracks, barrier-free access, shops, DB services, and direct connections to local buses and taxis.

RE27
Bergen(Ruegen) - Sassnitz Ferry terminal

Bergen(Ruegen)
Bergen is the district town of Ruegen and is the most populous city on Ruegen. It is one of the central traffic hubs of the island of Ruegen. It has facilities such as bicycle parking, parking spaces, and taxis. The DB Travel Center offers personal consultation and ticket sales.
Sassnitz Ferry terminal
Sassnitz Faehrhafen station sits directly within the Mukran Port complex on the island of Ruegen, providing seamless rail‑to‑ferry connections to Rønne (Bornholm) and Trelleborg (Sweden). It is the western terminus of the seasonal RE27 service, operated by Hanseatische Eisenbahn, which runs primarily on Saturdays and Sundays between May and October, offering one or two trains per direction per day timed to ferry departures and arrivals

Zu|g|ebringer
Bergen(Ruegen) - Lauterbach Pier

Bergen(Ruegen)
Bergen is the district town of Ruegen and is the most populous city on Ruegen. It is one of the central traffic hubs of the island of Ruegen. It has facilities such as bicycle parking, parking spaces, and taxis. The DB Travel Center offers personal consultation and ticket sales.
Putbus
Putbus is a small town on the island of Ruegen with about 4,000 residents. The Putbus train station is located in the center of the town and is served by the Ruegensche Kleinbahn, a narrow-gauge railway that connects Putbus with Binz, Goehren, and Lauterbach. The station building is a listed building and was built in 1899.
Lauterbach
It is located on the single‑track branch line from Bergen auf Ruegen to Lauterbach Mole. This standard‑gauge halt connects the small harbour town of Lauterbach to Putbus and beyond.
Lauterbach Pier
Lauterbach Mole station is the dual‑gauge terminus (standard + 750 mm narrow gauge) at the edge of the Ruegischer Bodden. It functions as a “Zugbringer” (feeder train) for passengers transferring between the Regio‑Shuttle services and the historic steam‑hauled Rasender Roland.

Racing Roland
Lauterbach Pier - Goehren

Lauterbach Pier
Lauterbach Mole station is the dual‑gauge terminus (standard + 750 mm narrow gauge) at the edge of the Ruegischer Bodden. It functions as a “Zugbringer” (feeder train) for passengers transferring between the Regio‑Shuttle services and the historic steam‑hauled Rasender Roland.
Lauterbach
It is located on the single‑track branch line from Bergen auf Ruegen to Lauterbach Mole. This standard‑gauge halt connects the small harbour town of Lauterbach to Putbus and beyond.
Putbus
Putbus is a small town on the island of Ruegen with about 4,000 residents. The Putbus train station is located in the center of the town and is served by the Ruegensche Kleinbahn, a narrow-gauge railway that connects Putbus with Binz, Goehren, and Lauterbach. The station building is a listed building and was built in 1899.
Beuchow
Beuchow is a small village on the island of Ruegen with about 200 residents. The Beuchow train station is located in the center of the village and is served by the Ruegensche Kleinbahn, a narrow-gauge railway that connects Beuchow with Putbus and Lauterbach. The station building is a listed building and was built in 1899.
Posewald
Posewald is a request halt at the forest edge, ideal for exploring the Biosphere Reserve trails.
Seelvitz
Seelvitz is a small village stop on the Moenchgut peninsula, providing access to nearby farms and footpaths.
Serams
Serams is a rural town surrounded by open fields and orchards.
Binz LB
It is located in the north of Binz’s main station, this tiny stop gives walkers direct access to coastal woodland paths.
Hunting lodge Granitz
It is the only halt in the heart of the Granitz forest; it’s the drop‑off point for the 19th‑century hunting lodge of the Prince of Putbus.
Garftitz
It serves the village of Garftitz, offering a gateway to local farm stays and quiet country lanes.
Sellin West
On the western edge of the resort town Sellin, this halt is closest to the Sellin sand dunes and western forest park
Sellin East
The eastern Sellin station sits near the historic pier and newly restored station building, acting as a scheduled crossing point for trains in high season.
Baabe
Directly in the coastal spa town of Baabe, known for its beach promenade, Baaber Bollwerk and colourful bathhouses.
Philippshagen
Is a request halt serving the small settlement of Philippshagen, famous for its half‑timbered houses.
Goehren
The eastern terminus at the seaside resort of Goehren, featuring classic resort architecture, a sandy beach and the pier at Seebruecke

Trains of Ruegen

Information on taking pictures from trains

for more details look at
DB - only in german.
The most important Informations are:
If you make pictures from trains, do not use these for commercial activities. Do not enter the track-area. Do not use Auxiliary means/Tools such as light resources, ladders, Drones, round throw Cameras and other stuff that iritating people. Do not cause delay, and let the emergency ways free. Understand the law of personal picture, from the train drivers.
